title: Lee Sin has 50% win  rate and 40% pickrate. Other champions have been gutted for less, much less.
body: This means that you will start to see Lee in pretty much every game you play, by either an ally or an enemy. This is insane, what happened to champion diversity. How many Lee Sin's in a row can you see before you go crazy.

replies.body: Lee Sin upcoming nerf not strong enough.
For an ignoramus like me, what are the upcoming Lee Sin nerfs? I keep hearing about them, but I don't know where to find them, unless I missed them on Surrender @ 20.

-5 ms, and up of ult cd.

Dont listen these bronze about balancing. Lee sin is hard nerfed (deserved).

Hard? 

His movement ist still faster than most others champions, in fact there's only 14 champs that are faster than him, and he's even got a 4 second slow along his two gap closers.
10 ms would actually mean he'd be caught by most of the bruisers, so he'd have to play smart.

This changes almost nothing.

-5 MS hurts so much early it's not funny. It probably adds a good 30 sec - 1 minute to that first full jg clear, or about 20 seconds for a given side. Counter jungling with him (especially pre-6, when your ward supply is lower) will be much harder, and give him windows where if he's spotted, a collapse is a real possibility.

It also makes him harder to gank with, because if he does not land the Q to gap close, anyone seeing him coming should have enough of a lead to reach tower before he can get there -- assuming one actually, you know, wards and pays attention. Any root/snare will basically deny a gank also, since you can root and run.

They did the same thing to Vi a little while back, and that's about the effect it had on me while playing her.
"Will be much harder" In what world does -5 movement speed make something "Much Harder", a bit harder, maybe, but you lost every bit of credibility when you said "Much Harder".

Have you ever jungled? Losing that move speed means slower travel times to everywhere. It adds up. It's meant to hit his early game, when he doesn't have a lot of wards stashed to ward hop with, and it takes the most time to clear camps. Figure the -5 ms will make the first gank come about 20-30 seconds later than it currently does (most common route is to start at a buff or raptors, clear that side, then gank). Unless, of course, he gets a harder leash from his laner.

That early in the game, it's enough that Lee won't have a level advantage any longer over the laner he's trying to gank.

If he's going to counter jungle instead of gank, say... start raptors, clear red, then go for blue, it'll take about 10 seconds longer to make the run. That's enough time for most current meta junglers to either reach and contest the blue while he's there, and his escape is delayed enough that if he's caught out like that it's entirely possible he's killed, because now he's moving slower. If a laner collapses on the spot and has any form of cc, he's certainly dead. If that goes down, Lee's not relevant for at least the next couple minutes as he'll be at least two levels behind any gank targets by the time he gets back out into the field, and is likely losing some of his jungle.

Comparing Winrates alone doesn't provide any good basis for discussion. You're comparing a Tanky, Front line Juggernaut, to a squishy, mobile mage. They're going to have different standards for how they should be balanced, and what is considered balanced for them.

Comparing them in a Void is dumb. In a void, which sounds worse? A mobile squishy mage being strong and killing people, or a Tanky Juggernaut being strong and killing people? You can CC a squishy and burst her down, but a Tanky Jugg like Voli is going to take a lot more than just CC to kill him.  This is ignoring other factors, like a Team peeling for people, or having other champions on your team that help/synergize with them. 

You ignore the basic principles of game design if you balance on numbers alone. You can't ignore the game they actually play in, and the different variety of champions that play very uniquely to each other, and that is a huge part. Someone like Voli, whose natural weakness is being Kited and peeled off by a good team, is much more a balance problem when at a higher winrate, since it means a not that hard to exploit weakness, is not enough for him to be kept in line.

And now to the main topic.

Winrate is combination of everything champion has. And even players skill aswell. Every champion uses the same system to evaluate their winrate, thus in almost all cases one winrate is perfect tool to compare champions, no matter their role, items, classes etc. Obviously, it shouldn't be used as only source of comparison, as for example number of games is important statistic that go together with winrate.

Which boils to just one thing: Marcus used winrate to compare champions properly. You on the other hand twisted meaning of his posts and started arguing with your version of what he said (strawmans argument at its finest).

Just to make sure there's no place to twist champion-comparing logic any further.

If Marcus would have compared Ahris AP to Volibears dance animation, or her HP to Volibears HP, then I'd be with you on this one. But he did not. He used statistic all champions share and are even balanced according to it: The holy winrate.

That's not strawman, it's simply what was implied due to his lack of details. If you compare two champions with winrate, that's faulty, because a lot of champions are different. If you compare two similar champions, let's say Xerath v. Ziggs, they're both mages, they're both siege champs, and they both have long range, than that's a more apt comparison for winrates. 

> on a 53% winrate 

That is a stat. 

Yes, every champion has stats, BUT what is the norm for each stat is completely different per champion. High Skill Champions have lower average, but higher Main winrates. Low Skill champions have higher base, but lower main winrates. Champs who scale have a higher winrate later in the game, than champs who have good bases. 

You can not look at stats alone, without looking at the Champions being compared. Yes, all champs have winrates, but they are balanced according to it differently based on the type of champion they are. 50% winrate is fine on someone on Alistar, but not someone like Azir. That's the difference you're missing. 

Winrate is not a flat baseline for all champions. Each champion has their own baseline for their own health, because they are different champions. 

~~technically, you're Strawmanning my argument too, except I don't need to rely on a fallacy to disprove your point~~

You are still wrong. 

You are arguing that winrate is an unfair comparison between two champions because one is a tank while the other is an mage. 

So what you are telling us is that tanks are supposed to have poor winrates whereas Ahri is supposed to have an high one, but that is not true and it is basically the pure definition of balance. 

If a particular champion has a high winrate it's for a reason, usually it's that some stat or ability or entire kit that gives them an innate advantage over would be opponents. 

An Azir was particulary balanced for having a really high winrate, and now he has a really low winrate.
